qas.question: What suffered considerably for Warsaw when it had an Eastern Bloc economy?

Why has Warsaw seen many improvements over the past decade?

context: Like many cities in Central and Eastern Europe, <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b4_0>infrastructure<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> in Warsaw suffered considerably during its time as an Eastern Bloc economy – though it is worth mentioning that the initial <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b5_0>Three-Year Plan<b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> to rebuild Poland (especially Warsaw) was a major success, but what followed was very much the opposite. However, <b8_0>over the past decade<b8_0/> Warsaw has seen many improvements due to <a2_0><a2_1><b6_0>solid <a2_2>economic growth<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, an increase in foreign investment as well as funding from the European Union. In particular, the city's metro, roads, sidewalks, health care facilities and sanitation facilities have <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>improved markedly<b7_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>.
